title: Free-body diagrams - cart on inclined track

content.question: A cart rolls along a track that is inclined at an angle of <math alttext="37 degrees" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>37</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">Â°</mi></math> to the horizontal, as shown. At the moment shown, there are three forces exerted on the cart: a downward force of magnitude <math alttext="50 newtons" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>50</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math>, a drag force of magnitude <math alttext="20 newtons" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math>, and a normal force from the track of magnitude <math alttext="40 newtons" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>40</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math>, as shown in the free-body diagram. The magnitude of the vector sum of the forces on the cart is most nearly

<math alttext="10 newtons" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mn>10</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math>
<math alttext="20 newtons" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mn>20</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math>
<math alttext="110 newtons" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>110</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math>

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
